title-group.article-title: Psilostachyins as trypanocidal compounds: Bioguided fractionation of Ambrosia tenuifolia chemically modified extract

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Medina Allende, Ciudad Universitaria, CP, X

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Psilostachyins as trypanocidal compounds: Bioguided fractionation of
Ambrosia tenuifolia
chemically modified extract

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Tonino G. Adessi
a , b
, Yamile Ana a, c , Cinthia C. Stempin a, c , M´onica C. García

Fabricio R. Bisogno a, e , Viviana E. Nicotra a, b , Manuela E. García

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Bioguided fractionation
Extract modifications
Trypanocidal compounds
Structure activity relationships
Sesquiterpene lactones
Psilostachyins
A B S T R A C T

This work focusses on the chemical diversification of an
Ambrosia tenuifolia
extract and its bioguided fractionation, aiming to unveil the chemical entity responsible for the trypanocidal activity. Besides, a revision of the phytochemical study of this species, based on previous reports of the antiparasitic psilostachyins A and C as main compounds, was conducted. To improve the biological properties of a plant extract through a simple chemical reaction, the oxidative diversification of the dichloromethane extract of this plant species was carried out. A bioguided fractionation of a chemically modified extract was performed by evaluating the inhibitory activity against
Trypanosoma cruzi
trypomastigotes. This experiment led to the isolation of one of the most active compounds. In general terms, epoxidized metabolites were obtained as a result of the oxidation of the major metabolite of the species. The trypanocidal activity of some tested metabolites overperformed the reference drug, benznidazole, displaying no cytotoxicity at trypanocidal concentrations. Key structure-activity relationships were obtained for designing previously undescribed antiparasitic sesquiterpene lactones.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: * Corresponding author. IMBIV-CONICET, Dpto. de Química Org´anica, Facultad de Ciencias Químicas, Universidad Nacional de C´ordoba, Edificio de Ciencias Químicas 2, Haya de la Torre y Medina Allende, Ciudad Universitaria, CP, X 5000HUA, Cordoba ´, Argentina .
E-mail address: manuelagarcia@unc.edu.ar (M.E. García).

Drug discovery, normally carried out by the pharmaceutical industry, involves a long and expensive process with an estimated duration of, at least, 15 years. Regarding diseases caused by trypanosomatids, such process is often neglected by the pharmaceutical industry. Therefore, the academy plays an essential role in the discovery, optimization, and development of trypanocidal therapeutic agents. It should be noted that these efforts are not currently underway; thus, more fruitful and cost-effective methodologies for obtaining safe compounds with significant trypanocidal activity are urgently required (Declaration of the Global Chagas Disease Coalition,).

Since the 1990s, there has been a renewed interest in herbal medicine, and research on the antiprotozoal effects of plants has been conducted. Several studies of extracts of raw plants, fractions, and pure compounds have allowed the identification of potential treatments for Chagas disease, reducing parasitemia, and showing low cytotoxicity for mammalian cells (
).

One feasible technique for obtaining diversity in natural products, as demonstrated in recent reports, is to strengthen nature’ s biosynthetic machinery. This goal is accomplished by chemically modifying vegetal extracts to produce a wide range of previously unknown semi-synthetic chemicals in a single step (Lopez´et al., 2007;
).

Through the chemical diversification of natural product mixtures, the resulting extracts have different composition, proportions, and biomolecular properties from those of their non-modified parents, depending on the type of introduced functionality (M´endez et al., 2011). In terms of practical operation and scope, this is an appealing and alternative proposal for building molecules similar to natural products in one step.

Given the background of the trypanocidal activity of the main metabolites of the
Ambrosia tenuifolia Spreng. (Asteraceae)
species, and the possibility of improving the biological properties of a plant extract through a simple chemical reaction, the dichloromethane ( CH 2 Cl 2 ) extract of this plant was diversified. A bioguided fractionation of a modified extract was performed by analyzing the anti-
Trypanosoma cruzi
activity. The pursued objective is to improve the trypanocidal effect through a simple oxidative modification that affects polarity, geometry, stereocenters, among other properties, as well as to identify and characterize the chemical entities responsible for the recorded activity.

sec.title: 2.1. Phytochemical study
sec.p: Performing a phytochemical review has two basic purposes. Firstly, it is well-known that species variability, together with factors such as season of collection, geographical location, and climate affect the content and relative quantity of specific metabolites of interest. Secondly, improving the biological properties through the derivatization of the extract requires prior knowledge of the chemical composition for comparative purposes.

sec.title: 2.2. Extract derivatization
sec.p: Due to these characteristics, this oxidant was the reagent chosen to perform the oxygen enrichment of this plant species extract. In our experience, SLs are unstable at high temperatures and extreme pH, therefore a reagent enabling oxidation reactions under mild conditions is an essential requirement.

Before the modification of the extract, it was necessary to optimize the reaction conditions with a model and abundant compound (Psi B, as substrate). The reaction time and temperature varied in addition to the use of a mild base (NaHCO 3 ). The conversion was evaluated by 1 H-NMR, monitoring the disappearance of key Psi B signals; total conversion was observed in all cases. The absence of base was determined to be the best condition, since no m -chlorobenzoic acid residues were observed at the end of the work-up [ m CPBA (2.4 eq), 24 h, 25 ◦ C in CH 2 Cl 2 ]. For more details, see figure S1 (Supporting information).

Usually, reactions on extracts result in an even more complex mixture, including unreacted reagents and unwanted products. In general, components are difficult to purify and, therefore, incompatible with any bioassay. In this case, the reaction was very clean, and pure compounds were easily obtained after a single purification step in all cases.

sec.title: 2.3. Bioguided fractionation of modified extract
sec.p: In a first step, the entire plant extract ( CH 2 Cl 2 ) was partitioned with solvents of increasing polarity, yielding 3 subextracts of different polarity (hexane, CH 2 Cl 2 and EtOAc). From these, the CH 2 Cl 2 extract contained the main part of its mass in SLs (evidenced by 1 H-NMR). For this reason, extract derivatization with the previously reagent ( m CPBA) was selected.

The modified extract from
A. tenuifolia
was subjected to bioguided fractionation as depicted in Fig. 2A , following their antiparasitic activity (as described in section 2.4). The resultant pools were subjected to chromatographic separation, and the pure compounds suitable for biological assays were obtained. From the purification of the different pools, only two major natural SLs, already present in the extract before being derivatized (Psi A and C), were isolated since they did not react with m CPBA. Furthermore, the SLs paulitine and isopaulitin, which have been reported as components of another
Ambrosia species
, were also isolated (
). Interestingly, these SLs were not detectable components in the unmodified extract under the working conditions used and would have been obtained from Psi B by epoxidation and subsequent reactions. Finally, three previously undescribed derivatives were obtained, compounds 1 , 2 and 3 . Compounds 2 and 3 , were formed as a result of the epoxidation of Psi B, which was consumed after the reaction. Compound 1 was obtained presumably by the transesterification of compound 2 , see Fig. 3 . For details regarding their structural elucidation, see the supplementary information (discussion and NMR spectra).
2.4. Biological assays

The effect of SLs on
T. cruzi
trypomastigotes (the infective stage of the parasite) was evaluated in vitro . The life cycle is divided into three stages; amastigotes and trypomastigotes are present in the mammalian host, whereas mainly infectious metacyclic epimastigotes are present in the insect vector. To calculate the inhibition percentage and IC 50 values, live parasites were counted by optical direct microscopy after treatment, using the vehicle DMSO or benznidazole as negative and positive controls, respectively.

Intriguingly, as shown in Figure S6 (see supplementary information), the total extract was inactive, and began to reveal trypanocidal activity as the amount of SLs present in the partition fractions increased (more specifically in the CH 2 Cl 2 extract). This may be due to an antagonistic effect caused by other compounds present in the initial mixture or by a dilution effect.

As observed in Fig. 2B , three fractions (pools II, III and IV) exhibited higher antiparasitic activity compared to the other samples (pool I, V, VI). Interestingly, pool III exhibited the highest trypanocidal activity, which was similar to that of benznidazole (
p >
0.05).

The isolated pure compounds after chemical modification of SLs extract were evaluated at concentrations of 1, 5 and 10 μg/mL ( Fig. 2C ). The IC 50 values were calculated for those that showed the highest
anti-T. cruzi
activity ( Table 1 ).

In general terms, SLs showed an outstanding trypanocidal activity, in some cases comparable to or significantly higher than that exhibited by the reference drug, benznidazole (IC 50 = 4.2 μM,
p <
0.005). Nonetheless, the results can be organized into three groups. The first group includes the compounds that were inactive or had lower inhibitory activity than Psi B (the main chemical precursor of the obtained derivatives). 4- Oxobedfordia acid and compound 1 (which showed an inhibition < 10 and 5%, respectively, at 5 μg/mL) were included in this group, as well as compound 2 and altamisin (% inhibition < 5 and < 10% at 1 and 5 μg/ mL, respectively, see Figure S7).

Psi A, B, isopaulitin and altamisic acid (precursor of Psi B, by ring closure lactonization) belong to the second group, showing a moderate activity (% inhibition ≤ 80% at 5 μg/mL, IC
50 in
the range 10–20 μM, Fig. 2C and S 7). The third group includes the most effective compounds (Psi C, paulitine and compound 3), which exhibited remarkable
anti-T. cruzi
activity (% inhibition > 75% at 5 μg/mL, IC 50 < 10 μM, Fig. 2C ).

Although for Psi A and C there are promising
T. cruzi
inhibition results previously reported (
), our findings on trypanocidal activity for Psi B suppose a starting point to find a better inhibition. This molecule differs from Psi C in a (C1–C10)-tetrasubstituted double bond, and though its activity is lower, it is a good and accessible precursor to other functionalities, both biosynthetically in nature and semi-synthetically in the laboratory.

The most substantial results were those shown by isopaulitin and paulitin, compounds that were not detected in the phytochemical study and obtained in appreciable quantities after derivatization. This pair of isomers only differs in the configuration of the epoxide ring stereocenters present in their structures. Even though their trypanocidal activity was good, the α- epoxy-isomer (paulitin) exhibited a 9-fold higher activity than the β- epoxy-isomer, isopaulitin (
p <
0.005). At this point, it is logical to assume that 1,10-epoxy motif is a molecular enhancer for the trypanocidal activity that has been found in this family of compounds.

After the chemical modification of the extract, compounds 1, 2 and 3 were obtained, presumably from the epoxidation of Psi B and subsequent reactions (
; Zhu et al., 2001), probably due to keto-enol tautomerism (see Fig. 3 ).

Compounds 2 and 3 also showed an inversion of the epoxy configuration between the C-1 and C-10 positions as the only difference in their structures. The trypanocidal activity demonstrated the same trend as paulitin and isopaulitin; α- epoxide had a better activity (10-fold higher,
p <
0.005) than β- epoxide. It should be mentioned that the presence of conjugation in ring A on the lactone results in an improvement of the trypanocidal activity of epoxidized compounds.

Our work contributes with the discovery of simple, but very valuable and previously unexplored structure-activity relationships. This means that the presence of ring A is important for parasite inhibition, since lactone compounds showed better activity than their open chain ester counterparts. In this case, esterification of free carboxylic acid decreased the efficacy. More importantly, in compounds bearing 1,10-epoxide along with the 2,3-olefinic-double bound, the spatial disposition of the epoxide turns out to be key for enhancing the trypanocidal activity.

As previously stated of lactones, the cytotoxic effect of some SLs is attributed to the exomethylene group. Even though this position was not chemically modified in our trypanocidal candidates, an evaluation of the impact of these structural changes on the cytotoxicity of the SLs was necessary. As discussed above, the addition of epoxide groups, in certain cases, may increase electrophilicity and reactivity. In consequence, the cytotoxicity of the compounds was evaluated on the macrophages cell line ( Table 1 ). CC 50 was measured for the most active compounds of the series (IC 50 < 7 μM) together with the positive control (benznidazol) and Psi B (the chemical precursor of the derivatives obtained). At 5 μg/mL, the concentration at which they exhibited high trypanocidal activity, the more active compounds (lower IC 50 values) were non-toxic, according to ISO 10993-5 standards, since cell viabilities were higher than 75% (International Standards ISO, 2009). Therefore, this finding further broadens the horizons in the research for previously undescribed safe trypanocidal therapeutic agents.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p: Apart from traditional phytochemical isolation, which yielded various bioactive compounds, in this contribution, a simple alternative was explored with remarkable results.

Through derivatization of
A. tenuifolia
extract and, consequently, its bioguided fractionation, naturally occurring bioactive metabolites (such as paulitin, the most active compound) were obtained, although they are not initially detectable in this species. Using a readily available and inexpensive oxidizing reagent, m CPBA, derivatization was achieved under mild conditions, allowing simple purification with almost total isolated mass recovery.

Epoxide-containing compounds, either naturally occurring or obtained by chemical modification, allowed arriving at a key structural motif regarding trypanocidal activity. As described in medicinal chemistry, a small structural change is capable of translating into an important change in biological activity (
). The configuration of the epoxy group (along with its intrinsic characteristic of being an electrophile capable of reacting with cellular nucleophiles as well as a hydrogen bond acceptor) proves to be a molecular determinant to increase parasite inhibition. To date, this is a novel finding that will serve as the foundation for future research aimed at the synthesis of more active and selective derivatives with less toxicity. Furthermore, it is the starting point for a mechanistic study of parasite growth inhibition at different stages, which may lead to finding the molecular target. This is still one of the biggest questions in this field of research and reaching consensus on it represents a difficult challenge.

These data, together with an in silico structural study of these molecules on biological targets of the parasite, would be very valuable to define their mechanism of action. In this regard, further molecular and biological evidence will allow a more efficient design of therapeutic trypanocidal agents.

sec.title: 4.1. General
sec.p: Optical rotation was measured on a JASCO P-1010 polarimeter. IR spectra were obtained in a Nicolet iZ10 ThermoScientific spectrophotometer (each compound was dissolved in a minimum amount of solvent, and a drop of solution was added to the AgCl IR plates). NMR experiments were performed on a Bruker AVANCE II 400 MHz instrument. Multiplicity determinations (HSQC-DEPT) and 2D spectra (COSY, HSQC, and HMBC) were obtained using standard Bruker software. Chemical shifts are expressed in ppm (δ) units using tetramethylsilane as the standard. Exact mass spectra were obtained on a Bruker microTOF-Q II mass spectrometer, equipped with an ESI source operating in positive mode. Chromatographic separations were performed by column chromatography and vacuum on silica gel 60 ( 0.063 –0.200 mm), flash chromatography on Sepacore® X10 and X50, and preparative TLC on silica gel 60 F 254 ( 0.2 mm thick) plates. The presence of compounds was revealed by an anisaldehyde reagent.
4.2. Plant material

The aerial parts of
Ambrosia tenuifolia Spreng. (Asteraceae)
were collected in Río de los Sauces ( 32.535932 ; 64.589681 ), Calamuchita Department , Cordoba ´, Argentina , in
February 2017
. The plant material was identified by Gloria Barboza (IMBIV-CONICET, Cordoba´, Argentina), and a voucher specimen was deposited on the Museo Bot´anico de C´ordoba ( CORD 00098343 ), Universidad Nacional de C´ordoba
.
4.3. Crude extracts

The dried and powdered aerial parts of
A. tenuifolia
( 450 g ) were extracted with CH 2 Cl 2 exhaustively at room temperature by five extraction cycles, and the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure. This extract (40.0 g) was suspended in EtOH–H 2 O (1:1) and washed with n-hexane (after extraction, 15.0 g), after which the EtOH was evaporated under reduced pressure. The residue was diluted with H 2 O and extracted with CH 2 Cl 2 (20.0 g), and finally with EtOAc ( 1.2 g ). The combined CH 2 Cl 2 phases were dried (Na 2 SO 4 ), filtered, and evaporated to dryness.
4.4. Extraction and isolation of control extract

CH 2 Cl 2 fraction ( 19.4 g ) was purified by vacuum chromatography on silica gel (hexane-EtOAc gradient) to yield five fractions. Fraction 1 (hexane/EtOAc, 60:40) was repurified by column chromatography, so 340.4 mg of altamisin and 5, 6 mg of 4-oxobedfordia acid were obtained. Fraction 2 (hexane/EtOAc, 50:50) was repurified by column chromatography (hexane/EtOAc), so 1.9 g of altamisin, 420.5 mg of psilostachyin A (Psi A) and 30.6 mg of altamisic acid were obtained. Fraction 3 (hexane/EtOAc, 40:60) resulted in 3.1 g of pure Psi A. Fraction 4 (hexane/EtOAc, 25:75) resulted in 7.6 g of pure psilostachyin B (Psi B). Fraction 5 (100% EtOAc) resulted in 2.8 g of psilostachyin C (Psi C). All compounds were determined to be > 95% pure by 1 H NMR spectroscopy.
4.5. Extract derivatization

To a solution of the CH 2 Cl 2 fraction ( 300 mg ) in CH 2 Cl 2 (15 mL) at 0 ◦ C, m -chloroperoxybenzoic acid 70% ( 325 mg , 1.32 mmol) was added, and the reaction was stirred for 24 h at room temperature. The reaction mixture was cooled in an ice bath, and the precipitated m- chlorobenzoic acid was removed by filtration. The organic layer was washed with Na 2 S 2 O 3 solution, then with NaHCO 3 solution, and finally, with H 2 O. The organic layer was dried with Na 2 SO 4 , filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure, obtaining 275 mg of modified extract, which resulted in a recovery percentage of 92% SLs and their derivatives.
4.5.1. Purification of the modified extract

The modified
A. tenuifolia
extract was chromatographed on silica gel (hexane-EtOAc-MeOH gradient) to yield six pools. Pool I (hexane/ EtOAc, 70:30) resulted in 12.5 mg of pure compound 1 , pool II (hexane/ EtOAc, 50:50) resulted in 33.9 mg of Psi A, pool III (hexane/EtOAc, 40:60) was repurified by column chromatography [ CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (5%) gradient], so 3.0 mg Psi A, 1.5 mg of paulitine, and 4.8 mg of isopaulitine were obtained. Pool IV (hexane/EtOAc, 30:70) was repurified by column chromatography [ CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (10%) gradient], so 12.3 mg of Psi C, 20.4 mg of compound 2 , and 26.1 mg of compound 3 were obtained. These compounds also were obtained from pool III in smaller proportions ( 9.6 mg and 4.9 mg , respectively). Pool V (hexane/EtOAc, 20:80) was repurified by column chromatography ( CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (20%) gradient), so 12.6 mg Psi C and 9.8 mg of compound 3 were obtained. Pool VI (EtOAc 100%) resulted in 31.1 mg of Psi C. All compounds were determined to be > 95% pure by 1 H NMR spectroscopy. For more details on the structural elucidation and tables of assignments, see supplementary information.
*n.m. Not measured.

Methyl-1β,10β- epoxy-altamisoate ( 1 ): White amorphous powder; [α] 25 D : 8.9 (c 0.01, acetone); UV (acetonitrile) λ max (log ε ) 216 (3.78) nm, 206 (3.38) nm; IR (dry film) ν max : 3451, 2928, 1738, 1444, 1379, 1004 cm 1 . HRESIMS m/z [M+ Na] + 333.1309 (calcd for C 16 H 22 NaO 6 + , 333.1309).

1β,10β- epoxy-psilostachyin B ( 2 ): White amorphous powder; [α] 25 D : 59.9 (c 0.001, Acetone); UV (Acetonitrile) λ max (log ε ) 280 (2.27) nm, 206 (3.73) nm; IR (dry film) ν max : 2923, 1762, 1263, 1109, 1062, 998 cm 1 . HRESIMS m/z [M+ Na] + 301.1039 (calcd for C 15 H 18 NaO 5 + , 301.1046).

1α,10α- epoxy-psilostachyin B ( 3 ): White amorphous powder; [α] 25 D : 28.7 (c 0.002, acetone); UV (acetonitrile) λ max (log ε ) 282 (2.51) nm, 206 (3.86) nm; IR (dry film) ν max : 2925, 1766, 1264, 1110, 1080, 996 cm 1 . HRESIMS m/z [M+ Na] + 301.1031 (calcd for C 15 H 18 NaO 5 + , 301.1046).

sec.title: 4.6.1. Obtention of Trypanosoma cruzi parasites
sec.p:
BALB/c mice, when 6–8 weeks old, were intraperitoneally infected with 1 × 10 6 blood-derived trypomastigote forms of
T. cruzi Tulahuen
strain, and the infection was maintained by intraperitoneal inoculation every 11 days. Then, trypomastigotes were used to infect Vero cell monolayers. After 7 days, supernatants were collected after centrifugation at 310× g for 20 min and resuspended in complete Roswell Park Memorial Institute medium (RPMI, Gibco Invitrogen Corporation) containing 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, Natocor), L-glutamine (2 mM, Gibco Invitrogen Corporation), and gentamicin ( 40 g /mL). Parasites were counted by direct microscopic observation using a Neubauer hemocytometer, and used for the in vitro experiments as described below, or stored at 80 ◦ C (
).

All animal experiments and procedures were carried out according to the guidelines of the Committee for Animal Care and Use of the Facultad de Ciencias Químicas, Universidad Nacional de C´ordoba, Argentina (Ethical Committee Approval Number HCD 942/18) in strict accordance with the recommendation of the Guide to the Care and Use of Experimental Animals published by the Canadian Council on Animal Care.

sec.title: 4.6.2. In vitro evaluation of antiprotozoal activity
sec.p:
Trypanocidal effects of natural compounds and derivatives were evaluated in trypomastigotes obtained as mentioned above. Parasites were resuspended in complete RPMI medium, and the concentration of parasites was adjusted to 1.5 × 10 6 /mL. Parasites were seeded (100 μL/ well) in triplicates in a 96-well microplate, and 100 μL of each compound/well (1–100 μg/mL, final concentration) was added. Benznidazole or DMSO was used as a control. The plates were incubated at 37 ◦ C in a relative humidity of 95% with 5% of CO 2 concentration for 24 h, and the remaining live parasites were counted in a Neubauer hemocytometer. Percent inhibition was calculated according to Equation (1) (
).
live parasites in wells after treatment
% inhibition = 100 × 100%
live parasites in untreated wells
Eq. 1
(50% low%) × (high[] low[])
IC 50 = + low[] Eq. 2 high% low%

where low% represents the highest percent of inhibition less than 50%, high% represents the lowest percent of inhibition greater than or equal to 50%, low [] represents the concentration of test compound that gives the low%, and high [] represents the concentration of test compound that gives the high%.

sec.title: 4.7. MTT assay
sec.p: RAW 264.7 macrophage cell line (ATCC) was seeded in 96-well microplates (3 × 104 cells/well) and grown overnight in Dulbecco’ s modified Eagle’ s medium (DMEM, Gibco Invitrogen Corporation). Then, they were treated for 24 h with the compounds at the concentrations described above. DMEM medium was used as a control. After that, culture supernatant media was removed, and 100 μL of 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide (MTT) solution (Sigma-Aldrich, 0.5 mg /mL) prepared in DMEM medium were added to each well. Cells were incubated for 4 h at 37 ◦ C and 5% CO 2. Next, 100 μL of DMSO was added into each well, and the microplates were kept for 15 min on the shaker. Absorbance (optical density, OD) was measured at 570 nm using an ELISA reader (BioRad). The percentage of cell viability was calculated using Equation (3):
OD experiment sample % cell viability = × 100% Eq.3
OD control

sec.title: 4.8. Statistical analysis
sec.p: Prism (GraphPad Software) was used to perform the statistical analyses, with all data expressed as mean ± SD. Data were analyzed using Student’ s t-test, and one- and two-way ANOVA, followed by Dunnett’ s post-test for multiple comparisons. Values of p < 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.113014.
